questions.question_text_1: In a message queue system, if the consumer is slower than the producer, what is likely to occur first?
question_texts: In a message queue system, if the consumer is slower than the producer, what is likely to occur first?

options.option_text: Messages will accumulate in the queue
The consumer will speed up automatically
The producer will block until the consumer is ready

question_texts: What does "reactivity" mean in the context of frontend frameworks like Vue.js?

options.option_text: The component will reload when data changes
It disables direct access to state
The DOM updates automatically when the underlying reactive data changes

It skips route execution for repeated inputs

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is/are the potential benefits of using a message broker?
question_texts: Which of the following is/are the potential benefits of using a message broker?

options.option_text: A message broker makes the network scalable for adding more servers to thenetwork.
A message broker allows two servers in a network to directly communicatewith each other, without an intermediary.
A message broker is not suited in case of traffic spikes, as messages areretained in the queue until processed.
A message broker can be used for batch processing of messages.

questions.question_text_1: Which statements about webhooks are correct?
question_texts: Which statements about webhooks are correct?

options.option_text: They use HTTP POST requests typically
They require polling from the client

questions.question_text_1:
A popular e-commerce platform needs to notify multiple third-party services (inventory management, email marketing, analytics) whenever a customer places an order. The development team is considering different approaches to handle these notifications. 
Scenario: When an order is placed, the system needs to: 
● Update inventory levels in an external warehouse system ● Send a welcome email through a third-party email service ● Log analytics data to an external tracking service ● Update customer loyalty points in a CRM system 
Which of the following statements about using webhooks for this scenario is MOST accurate?
question_texts:
A popular e-commerce platform needs to notify multiple third-party services (inventory management, email marketing, analytics) whenever a customer places an order. The development team is considering different approaches to handle these notifications. 
Scenario: When an order is placed, the system needs to: 
● Update inventory levels in an external warehouse system ● Send a welcome email through a third-party email service ● Log analytics data to an external tracking service ● Update customer loyalty points in a CRM system 
Which of the following statements about using webhooks for this scenario is MOST accurate?

options.option_text: Webhooks are not suitable for this use case because they require the e-commerce platform to continuously poll each third-party service to check if they're ready to receive data, which would create unnecessary network overhead.

Webhooks should be avoided in this scenario because they operatesynchronously, meaning the customer's order placement would be delayed until all third-party services have successfully processed their notifications.

Webhooks provide an ideal solution as they allow the e-commerce platform topush real-time notifications to all subscribed third-party services immediately when an order is placed, eliminating the need for these services to repeatedly poll for updates.
Webhooks are primarily designed for read-only operations and cannot handlecomplex data payloads like order information, making them unsuitable for e-commerce transaction notifications.

questions.question_text_1: What is the main advantage of using caching in a Flask-based web application?
question_texts: What is the main advantage of using caching in a Flask-based web application?

options.option_text: It eliminates the need for client-side rendering
It reduces server load by reusing responses for repeated requests
It encrypts data transmission between server and client
It avoids the need for database interactions completely

questions.question_text_1: Which statements are true about handling background tasks in Flask with Celery?
question_texts: Which statements are true about handling background tasks in Flask with Celery?

options.option_text: Using time.sleep() blocks the event loop and is recommended for async tasks
Celery allows long-running tasks to be executed asynchronously
Polling is a strategy to check task status periodically
Flask + Celery + Redis is a common stack for async task management

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are true about mutations and actions in Vuex?
question_texts: Which of the following are true about mutations and actions in Vuex?

options.option_text: Only actions can call APIs through fetch call
The class "active" will only be applied to the div element if the variable"isActive" evaluates to true.
The class "disabled" will be applied to the div element when the variable"isEnabled" evaluates to false.
The class "text-bold" will always be applied to the div element regardless ofthe "hasBoldText" variable value.
All three classes ("active", "text-bold", "disabled") will always be applied to thediv element.
If "isEnabled" is undefined, the "disabled" class will not be applied to the divelement.
The class "text-bold" will only be applied if the variable "hasBoldText" existsand evaluates to a truthy value.

questions.question_text_1:
Prashant and Nikita are creating a quiz question paper collaboratively. They are each working on different sections — and complete their tasks in parallel. Meanwhile, Mayur is enjoying a single-player game that finishes when the game loop ends. 
To compare productivity: 
● If Prashant and Nikita (together) finish faster than Mayur, the winner is "Team". ● If Mayur finishes faster, he wins. ● If both take the same time, Mayur wins by default. 
You are simulating this scenario in the browser.Prashant and Nikita are represented using parallel Promises. Mayur is represented using a single Promise. The frontend must calculate who finishes first using asynchronous logic, and display the result.

  Based on the above data and amswer the given subquestions.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and key equations** for the **"Modern Application Development II"** exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- --- ## **Core Topics & Concepts Summary** ### **1. Asynchronous JavaScript & Promises** - **Key Concepts**: - `async/await`, `Promise`, `.then()`, `.catch()`, `.finally()`. - **Event Loop**: Microtasks (Promises) vs. Macrotasks (setTimeout). - **Promise Methods**: - `Promise.all()`: Waits for all promises to resolve (fails if any reject). - `Promise.race()`: Resolves/rejects as soon as the first promise settles. - `Promise.allSettled()`: Waits for all promises to settle (resolved/rejected). - **Closures**: Functions retaining access to their lexical scope (e.g., counters). - **`this` Binding**: - Regular functions: `this` depends on how the function is called. - Arrow functions: `this` is lexically scoped (inherits from parent). - **Example Code Outputs**: ```javascript // Closure Example function createCounter() { let count = 0; return function() { count++; return count; }; } const counter = createCounter(); console.log(counter()); // 1 console.log(counter()); // 2 // Promise Race Example const team = Promise.all([task1, task2]).then(() => "Team"); const mayur = new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 2000, "Mayur")); Promise.race([team, mayur]).then(winner => console.log(winner)); ``` --- ### **2. Vue.js Core Concepts** #### **A. Reactivity** - **Definition**: Automatic DOM updates when underlying data changes. - **Reactive Properties**: `data()`, `computed`, `watch`. - **Caveats**: - Directly modifying array indices (e.g., `arr[0] = 1`) or object properties (e.g., `obj.newProp = 1`) **won’t trigger reactivity** unless using `Vue.set` or spreading (`{...obj}`). #### **B. Components & Props** - **Props**: Pass data from parent to child (one-way binding). - **Slots**: Distribute content from parent to child. - **Named Slots**: ``. - **Scoped Slots**: Pass data from child to parent (``). #### **C. Vuex (State Management)** - **State**: Single source of truth. - **Mutations**: Synchronous state changes (must be pure). - **Actions**: Asynchronous operations (can commit mutations). - **Getters**: Computed properties for state. - **Key Rules**: - **Mutations must be synchronous**. - **Actions can be async** (e.g., API calls). #### **D. Vue Router** - **Dynamic Routes**: `:id` in paths (e.g., `/user/:id`). - **Navigation Methods**: - `this.$router.push()`: Adds to history stack. - `this.$router.replace()`: Replaces current entry (no history stack). - `this.$router.go(-1)`: Navigates back. - **Named Routes**: Use `name` instead of `path` for navigation. #### **E. Class & Style Bindings** - **Object Syntax**: ```html
``` - **Array Syntax**: ```html
``` #### **F. Lifecycle Hooks** - `created()`: After instance creation (data/props available). - `mounted()`: After DOM insertion. - `updated()`: After reactive data changes. - `beforeDestroy()`: Before teardown. --- ### **3. Flask & Backend Concepts** #### **A. Caching** - **`@cache.cached()`**: Skips route execution for repeated inputs (reduces server load). - **Use Cases**: Expensive computations, API responses. #### **B. CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)** - **Purpose**: Control which domains can access resources. - **Flask-CORS Setup**: ```python from flask_cors import CORS app = Flask(__name__) CORS(app, resources={r"/api/*": {"origins": "http://example.com"}}) ``` #### **C. Celery (Async Task Queue)** - **Use Case**: Offload long-running tasks (e.g., sending emails). - **Stack**: Flask + Celery + Redis/RabbitMQ. - **Key Methods**: - `task.delay()`: Schedule a task. - `task.get()`: Get result (blocks until ready). - **Polling**: Check task status periodically. #### **D. Message Brokers (e.g., RabbitMQ)** - **Purpose**: Decouple producers/consumers. - **Benefits**: - Scalability (add more consumers). - Batch processing. - Handling traffic spikes (messages queue up). - **Webhooks vs. Polling**: - **Webhooks**: Push-based (real-time, server-to-server). - **Polling**: Client repeatedly checks for updates (inefficient). --- ### **4. Web Performance Optimization** #### **A. Lighthouse Metrics** - **First Contentful Paint (FCP)**: Time until first DOM content is rendered. - **Time to Interactive (TTI)**: Time until page is fully interactive. - **Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS)**: Visual stability (avoid unexpected layout shifts). #### **B. Performance Factors** - **Critical Rendering Path**: - Minimize render-blocking resources (CSS/JS). - Reduce HTTP requests (combine files, use sprites). - Compress resources (images, JS/CSS). - **Caching**: Reuse responses for repeated requests. - **Lazy Loading**: Load resources (images, iframes) only when needed. --- ### **5. Security Best Practices** #### **A. Supply Chain Attacks** - **Mitigations**: - **Version Pinning**: Lock dependency versions (e.g., `package.json`). - **Reduce Dependencies**: Audit and remove unused packages. - **Use Trusted Sources**: Avoid unmaintained packages. #### **B. CORS Misconfigurations** - **Risk**: Exposing APIs to unauthorized domains. - **Fix**: Restrict origins explicitly: ```python CORS(app, resources={r"/api/*": {"origins": ["https://trusted.com"]}}) ``` #### **C. Secure Storage** - **`localStorage` vs. `sessionStorage`**: - `localStorage`: Persists across sessions (vulnerable to XSS). - `sessionStorage`: Cleared when tab closes. - **Avoid Storing Secrets**: Use `HttpOnly` cookies for sensitive data. --- ### **6. Frontend Frameworks (Vue.js)** #### **A. Reactivity System** - **How it Works**: - Vue converts `data` properties into getters/setters (Proxy in Vue 3). - Dependencies are tracked during rendering. - Re-renders when dependencies change. #### **B. Template Syntax** - **Interpolation**: `{{ message }}`. - **Directives**: - `v-if`/`v-show`: Conditional rendering. - `v-for`: Loop over arrays/objects. - `v-bind`: Bind attributes (`:class`, `:style`). - `v-on`: Event listeners (`@click`). #### **C. Computed vs. Watched Properties** | **Computed** | **Watched** | |----------------------------|---------------------------------| | Cached (recomputes only if dependencies change). | Runs on specific data changes. | | Use for derived data. | Use for async/side effects. | --- ### **7. Modern JavaScript (ES6+)** #### **A. Destructuring** ```javascript const { name, ...rest } = user; // Extract `name`, rest in `rest` const newUser = { ...rest, location: city }; // Spread operator ``` #### **B. Arrow Functions** - **No `this` binding**: Inherits from parent scope. - **Implicit Return**: `() => expression`. #### **C. Modules** - **Export**: `export default` or named exports (`export const x = 1`). - **Import**: `import x from './module'` or `import { x } from './module'`. --- ## **Key Equations/Code Snippets** ### **1. Promise Race/All** ```javascript // Team wins if both Prashant and Nikita finish before Mayur const team = Promise.all([prashant, nikita]).then(() => "Team"); const winner = await Promise.race([team, mayur]); ``` ### **2. Vuex Mutation vs. Action** ```javascript // Mutation (synchronous) mutations: { SET_USER(state, user) { state.user = user; } }, // Action (asynchronous) actions: { async fetchUser({ commit }, id) { const user = await api.getUser(id); commit('SET_USER', user); } } ``` ### **3. Flask Caching** ```python from flask_caching import Cache cache = Cache(app, config={'CACHE_TYPE': 'SimpleCache'}) @app.route('/expensive') @cache.cached(timeout=60) # Cache for 60 seconds def expensive(): return compute_expensive_result() ``` ### **4. Vue Reactivity Caveat** ```javascript // Won't trigger reactivity: this.myObject.newProp = 'value'; // Bad this.myArray[0] = 1; // Bad // Good (reactive): this.$set(this.myObject, 'newProp', 'value'); this.myArray.splice(0, 1, 1); ``` ### **5. CORS in Flask** ```python from flask_cors import CORS app = Flask(__name__) CORS(app, resources={ r"/api/*": { "origins": ["http://localhost:3000", "https://trusted.com"] } }) ``` --- ## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** ### **Graph 1: Asynchronous JavaScript Ecosystem** ```mermaid graph TD A[Asynchronous JavaScript] --> B[Promises] A --> C[Async/Await] A --> D[Event Loop] B --> E[Promise.all] B --> F[Promise.race] B --> G[Promise.allSettled] D --> H[Microtasks] D --> I[Macrotasks] H --> J[Promise Callbacks] I --> K[setTimeout/setInterval] ``` ### **Graph 2: Vue.js Core Architecture** ```mermaid graph TD A[Vue Instance] --> B[Reactivity System] A --> C[Template] A --> D[Components] B --> E[Data] B --> F[Computed Properties] B --> G[Watchers] C --> H[Directives] C --> I[Slots] D --> J[Props] D --> K[Lifecycle Hooks] A --> L[Vuex] L --> M[State] L --> N[Mutations] L --> O[Actions] L --> P[Getters] ``` ### **Graph 3: Flask Backend Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[Flask] --> B[Routing] A --> C[Caching] A --> D[CORS] A --> E[Async Tasks] B --> F[@app.route] C --> G[@cache.cached] D --> H[Flask-CORS] E --> I[Celery] I --> J[Redis/RabbitMQ] I --> K[Task Queues] ``` ### **Graph 4: Web
